newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil corporate debt levels up 39 pct in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Brazil corporate debt levels up 39 pct in 1996.

text.p: Brazil's corporate debt levels rose 39 percent in the first three quarters of 1996 against the same period last year as firms rushed to finance plant expansion to improve competitiveness, a private survey showed.

"The increase in corporate debt levels is healthy for Brazilian companies because these funds were used to invest in production and not cover deficits," said Jorge Kotani, of the Lafis consultancy firm which sponsored the survey.

According to the study, which surveyed 30 Brazilian companies in several sectors, corporate indebtness as a share of the net worth rose to 51.59 percent in the first nine months of the year from 37.1 percent in the same period last year.
Debt levels are expected to continue growing in 1997, although Brazil's political outlook are likely to weigh on management's decision whether or not to invest, Kotani said.
President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who in 1994 was elected to a four-year term, is seeking a constitutional amendment which would allow him to seek a second term in office.

Kotani said Brazilian companies have also improved their margins due to reestructuring. He said gross margins between January and September jumped to 47.72 percent of total sales against 22.03 percent a year ago.
Nine-month net margins doubled to 4.62 percent from 2.1 percent a year earlier, he said.
